article_text: The Australian Education Union today called on all governments to commit to ending the underfunding of public schools as a matter of urgency saying the future of the teaching profession is at stake along with the quality of education delivered across the nation.  AEU Federal President Correna Haythorpe welcomed news today that WA is going to be the first state to commit to fully funding public schools by 2026.  But Ms Haythorpe said there needed to be a bigger investment than the one proposed by the Commonwealth and the WA Government to achieve that goal.  "Right now, only 1.3% of public schools are funded to the Schooling Resource Standard (SRS) which is the minimum level governments agreed over a decade ago was required to meet the needs of their students," Ms Haythorpe said.  "We applaud the commitment by the Federal Education Minister Jason Clare and the WA Government to get schools to 100% of the SRS by 2026. However, today's agreement will only see WA public schools reach 96% of the SRS.  "WA's SRS funding share is artificially inflated by 4% through the inclusion of costs not directly related to the education of students in schools, such as capital depreciation, transport and regulatory costs. That 4% of the SRS was worth $230 million for WA in 2023 and that money still needs to be delivered to WA public schools before schools are truly funded at 100% of the SRS.  "This has to be the first step rather than the final agreement.  "With full funding principals and teachers can change the lives of students across the nation. It will mean more help for children at risk of falling behind and more support for teachers inside and outside of the classroom to cut their workloads and help address the growing needs of students.  "Short-changing our schools is short-changing our students at a time when we can least afford it. The challenges are too great and the human costs too high not to fully resource our schools.  "We have a teacher shortage crisis caused by crippling workloads, unacceptable achievement gaps between children from different backgrounds and locations and a worrying decline in student mental health and wellbeing."  Ms Haythorpe said all public schools across the nation should reach a genuine 100% of the SRS by 2028 with the Albanese Government lifting its share from 20% of the SRS to 25% of the SRS for states and 40% of the SRS in the NT.  There also needs to be a significant investment of capital funding in new bilateral agreements struck this year.  "The Commonwealth has underfunded public schools for decades while overfunding private schools. Only 1.6% of the federal budget is spent on public schools," she said.  "The Albanese Government's current offer of 22.5% of the SRS should be revised to 25% of the SRS for all states and 40% of the SRS for the NT by 2028."  Parliamentary Budget Office figures show that an average annual investment of just over $1.8 billion is required if the Commonwealth is to lift its funding share from 20% of the SRS this year to 25% by 2028.  Ms Haythorpe said an Expert Panel convened by education ministers in December warned the need for full funding in every state and territory was "urgent and critical" and the first step towards ensuring all students receive the support they need.  The panel said full funding must be delivered across the country "within a comparable timeline".  "As the Expert Panel found, funding gaps are fuelling unacceptable achievement gaps between students from different backgrounds and locations," Ms Haythorpe said.  "Disadvantaged secondary students are six times more likely to be low performers than those from advantaged backgrounds.  "Declining student mental health and wellbeing is a major source of concern and there are acute teacher shortages across the country caused by unsustainable workloads.  "We don't have a level playing field in education that ensures every child gets every opportunity to succeed. Fixing that starts with funding."

article_text: For Andrea Ferris, her horses are part of the family.  "They're just lovely to hang out with. Horses are very calming," she said.  On a scorching summer day, her four horses flick their tails and twitch their ears to shoo off pesky insects on the family property at Kilkivan, a three-hour drive north of Brisbane.  There have been times when the herd has been a substitute for human company to cope with the isolation and loneliness of being a newcomer to town.  Ms Ferris felt lonely in the early days of her relocation to Kilkivan. ( ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside )  When Ms Ferris and her husband moved to the area in early 2020, COVID-19 lockdowns threw a wrench in their plans to get to know the residents in the town of fewer than 700 people.  "It was very quiet," Ms Ferris said.  "There was no socialisation at the time and I had to work at home … we didn't get a chance to really connect with the community."  Horses source of 'comfort and frustration'  Part of the lure of Kilkivan was its equine links – it's one of the towns on the National Trail and renowned for its annual Great Horse Ride.  The street parade is a much loved part of the Kilkivan Great Horse Ride. ( Facebook )  The couple planned to pack saddle the National Trail, a 5,000-kilometre journey following historic coach and stock routes, old pack horse trails, and country roads from Cooktown in far north Queensland to Healesville in Victoria.  But their plans were dashed when horse Pepper stood on Ms Ferris's foot, setting off a series of health issues that have lingered for months.  "The horses have been a source of comfort and frustration," Ms Ferris said.  "I look out the window during my recovery and think of all the things that I want to be doing with them."  Four years on from their relocation, Ms Ferris decided enough was enough and it was high time to finally get to know her community.  "I found myself stuck here at home after having surgeries, not being able to see anybody and not knowing anyone to talk to," she said.  "I thought, I really need to do something about that."  Ms Ferris estimated about 45 people attended the first event in December. ( Supplied: Andrea Ferris )  So, Kilkivan 4600 Connect was born.  The first social gathering brought together new and old faces from the postcode just before Christmas. It was so successful that residents are looking forward to the next one.  "About 45 new residents came," Ms Ferris said.  "I was over the moon."  Putting in the effort  Almost one in three Australians report feeling lonely, according to a 2023 report by not-for-profit organisation Ending Loneliness Together.  It also found there were more lonely people living in rural areas than metropolitan centres.  "[Regional areas] might not have as strong a community as we previously estimated," chief executive and scientific chair Michelle Lim said.  Michelle Lim says it can be difficult for new residents to integrate into well-established regional communities. ( Supplied: Michelle Lim )  Dr Lim said the fabric of rural communities was shifting as more people moved away from cities.  "There's some conflicting reports that if you live in a rural or regional town, you're more close-knit," she said.  "But if you're a new transplant from the city to a community that's rural or remote, it might take you some time to connect with that community."  Dr Lim said the key ingredients to integrating with the community were effort and time.  "Being friendly and being open will yield rewards, but this is something that is done over a period of time as opposed to immediately," she said.  "It doesn't have to be a big effort, but it has to be consistent over time."  'Innovative approach' connects people  Ms Ferris is slowly achieving that sense of belonging she's craved since moving to Kilkivan.  And through her community initiative, longtime residents like Rosie Fitzgerald are also reconnecting.  Rosie Fitzgerald says it was a fantastic event. ( ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside )  "I met a lot of new people I hadn't met before," Ms Fitzgerald, president of the Kilkivan and District Community Care Association, said.  "We were able to share our experience because some of us have been around for a while.  "I would like to congratulate Andrea on not just the success but also the innovative approach she used to be able to get organisations like ours in touch with other community members."

"They're just lovely to hang out with. Horses are very calming," she said. On a scorching summer day, her four horses flick their tails and twitch their ears to shoo off pesky insects on the family property at Kilkivan, a three-hour drive north of Brisbane. There have been times when the herd has been a substitute for human company to cope with the isolation and loneliness of being a newcomer to town. Ms Ferris felt lonely in the early days of her relocation to Kilkivan. ( ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside ) When Ms Ferris and her husband moved to the area in early 2020, COVID-19 lockdowns threw a wrench in their plans to get to know the residents in the town of fewer than 700 people. "It was very quiet," Ms Ferris said. "There was no socialisation at the time and I had to work at home … we didn't get a chance to really connect with the community." Horses source of 'comfort and frustration' Part of the lure of Kilkivan was its equine links – it's one of the towns on the National Trail and renowned for its annual Great Horse Ride. The street parade is a much loved part of the Kilkivan Great Horse Ride. ( Facebook ) The couple planned to pack saddle the National Trail, a 5,000-kilometre journey following historic coach and stock routes, old pack horse trails, and country roads from Cooktown in far north Queensland to Healesville in Victoria. But their plans were dashed when horse Pepper stood on Ms Ferris's foot, setting off a series of health issues that have lingered for months. "The horses have been a source of comfort and frustration," Ms Ferris said. "I look out the window during my recovery and think of all the things that I want to be doing with them." Four years on from their relocation, Ms Ferris decided enough was enough and it was high time to finally get to know her community. "I found myself stuck here at home after having surgeries, not being able to see anybody and not knowing anyone to talk to," she said. "I thought, I really need to do something about that." Ms Ferris estimated about 45 people attended the first event in December. ( Supplied: Andrea Ferris ) So, Kilkivan 4600 Connect was born. The first social gathering brought together new and old faces from the postcode just before Christmas. It was so successful that residents are looking forward to the next one. "About 45 new residents came," Ms Ferris said. "I was over the moon." Putting in the effort Almost one in three Australians report feeling lonely, according to a 2023 report by not-for-profit organisation Ending Loneliness Together. It also found there were more lonely people living in rural areas than metropolitan centres. "[Regional areas] might not have as strong a community as we previously estimated," chief executive and scientific chair Michelle Lim said. Michelle Lim says it can be difficult for new residents to integrate into well-established regional communities. ( Supplied: Michelle Lim ) Dr Lim said the fabric of rural communities was shifting as more people moved away from cities. "There's some conflicting reports that if you live in a rural or regional town, you're more close-knit," she said. Almost one-third of Australians feel lonely One in six Australians report feeling severely lonely, and the people we are least socially connected to are our neighbours, according to a landmark study. Read more "But if you're a new transplant from the city to a community that's rural or remote, it might take you some time to connect with that community." Dr Lim said the key ingredients to integrating with the community were effort and time. "Being friendly and being open will yield rewards, but this is something that is done over a period of time as opposed to immediately," she said. "It doesn't have to be a big effort, but it has to be consistent over time." 'Innovative approach' connects people Ms Ferris is slowly achieving that sense of belonging she's craved since moving to Kilkivan. And through her community initiative, longtime residents like Rosie Fitzgerald are also reconnecting. Rosie Fitzgerald says it was a fantastic event. ( ABC Wide Bay: Grace Whiteside ) "I met a lot of new people I hadn't met before," Ms Fitzgerald, president of the Kilkivan and District Community Care Association, said. "We were able to share our experience because some of us have been around for a while. "I would like to congratulate Andrea on not just the success but also the innovative approach she used to be able to get organisations like ours in touch with other community members." article_text: A “forgotten” box of cabinet records and a series of administrative errors are among the reasons why a tranche of Howard-era documents was mistakenly kept from public release earlier this year.  An independent review into why 82 cabinet records from 2003 were not handed to the national archives, released on Tuesday, found there was no political interference or influence at play.  Instead, the Covid-19 pandemic had become a “catalyst for a major breakdown” in the transfer of the Howard government records, including 14 which related – at least in part – to the government’s decision to join the Iraq war.  On the first day of each year, cabinet documents from 20 years prior are released to the public. Those documents are transferred from the prime minister and cabinet’s department (PM&C) to the national archives years earlier to be prepared for public release.  The former defence department secretary, Dennis Richardson, was appointed to lead a review after PM&C confirmed on New Year’s Day it had found 78 documents were mistakenly not transferred in 2020 due to “apparent administrative oversights”.  Another four documents were located on 4 January 2024 after department staff conducted another physical inspection.  Richardson’s found those oversights, exposed further by the pandemic, included an inconsistent understanding among staff of their archival obligations and a lack of staff with record-management experience.  “The particular pandemic-driven work environment of 2020 became the catalyst for a major breakdown which, given the compounding systemic issues, was probably inevitable at some point,” the report said.  Richardson’s review found pandemic restrictions in 2020 meant staff could not physically inspect the boxes of cabinet records to ensure no non-cabinet intelligence documents were accidentally included.  As a result, a box of cabinet documents was left in a “secure storage area” within the department pending an intelligence agency review. The review found it was then “subsequently forgotten”.  PM&C also told the review it held cabinet records in different locations due to their security classifications but had no central register.  During the course of the review, the department’s cabinet division revealed it had found 30 cabinet notebooks ranging from 1978 to 1992 that hadn’t been sent to the national archives.  Adding to the complexity, only staff with a top security clearance could access records in certain rooms.  In one case, once staff did gain access to a special security room, they were confronted with “several cabinets” no one in the cabinet division team had access to. Eventually, four cabinet records were located in a sealed envelope within the room.  “The material within the room holding cabinet records was poorly itemised, tailor-made for a mistake in a future transfer process from PM&C to the NAA,” the report said.  skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Morning Mail Free daily newsletter Our Australian morning briefing breaks down the key stories of the day, telling you what’s happening and why it matters Enter your email address Enter your email address Sign up Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy . We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. after newsletter promotion  Richardson recommended the department review its transfer process, train its staff to have “at least a basic understanding” of the Archives Act and ensure all staff dealing with cabinet records have top security clearance.  Richardson said the national archives had now received the extra 82 records. The archives will now review the documents for exempted material and consult intelligence agencies before a decision is made on their release.  National security committee (NSC) documents related to the Iraq war were largely missing from the huge volume of material released by the archives on New Year’s Day.  NSC records that do not go to cabinet are not automatically released but can be applied for release with a decision made by the information commissioner on a case-by-case basis.  One document included in the 1 January release showed the full cabinet signed off on the decision to send Australia to war on 18 March 2003 based on “oral reports by the prime minister”.  The document did not contain mention of any doubt about Iraq’s possession of weapons of mass destruction – the key justification for war – which proved to be false.  Of the original 77 missing cabinet records that were discovered, Richardson said 13 records, containing 38 NSC minutes, related to the war.  Upon announcing Richardson’s review into the archiving error, the prime minister, Anthony Albanese, said this month it was crucial Australians were told why Howard joined Australia in the US’s invasion.

article_text: In the aftermath of the latest flood to inundate her outback community, teacher Anne Pollock went to check on the state of her beloved workplace, the Pigeon Hole school.  This time around, it had managed to avoid serious devastation.  Less than 12 months earlier, however, the same building wasn't so fortunate.  The floors were left caked in hardened mud, with schoolbooks and classroom resources badly damaged and destroyed.  Floodwaters damaged property at the Pigeon Hole school in March 2023. ( Supplied )  For Ms Pollock, seeing her tiny outback Northern Territory community hit by floods from a swelling Victoria River twice in less than a year has proved a difficult pill to swallow.  "It was terrible, devastating you know?" the Bilinara and Mudburra woman said.  "Repeating the trauma again.  "After the flood last year, I lost a lot of my stuff from my house."  Anne Pollock says the flooding events have been "devastating" for residents. ( ABC News: Evelyn Manfield )  Dozens of residents were evacuated from Pigeon Hole — also known as Nitjpurru — earlier this month, as the river hit a 30-year peak of 24 metres, during a deluge from the tropical monsoon.  Located more than 700 kilometres south of Darwin and built on a flood plain, residents and local authorities have been calling for Pigeon Hole to be relocated to higher ground for decades.  Mayor of the Victoria Daly Regional Council Brian Pedwell has been raising his voice over the issue to the NT government for years, so far to no avail.  "I'm very angry. I've been angry for the last 20 years to relocate that community," he said.  "Those departments, when are they going to look at themselves deeply and relocate that infrastructure … how many more times that community gonna flood?"  Brian Pedwell has spent years pushing the NT government to move Pigeon Hole to higher ground. ( ABC News: Mike Donnelly )  Government says it supports relocating Pigeon Hole  NT Chief Minister Eva Lawler denied that the government had long ignored the requests of Pigeon Hole residents to relocate, and said negotiations were underway with a nearby cattle station for access to higher land.  "There is an absolute will to do that [relocation]," Ms Lawler said.  "These things cost money, and it is moving a whole community, and you know, there are people that have lived there for a very long time."  She didn't commit to a firm timeline and said there could be compensation involved with the move.  "With the pastoralists, you know, there will need to be land that'll be excised, it might involve compensation, and then it will be around that process of moving," she said.  Some of the houses sit on short stilts, but residents say it's not enough to escape floodwaters. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  The NT government built more houses on the flood plain in 2018. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  Founded by Australia's first billionaire, Robert Holmes à Court, Heytesbury Pastoral owns the Victoria River Downs station next to Pigeon Hole.  Station general manager Rusty Richter said the station had "no objections" to excising part of the station land for the town, but that they'd received very little information from the NT government.  "Heytesbury's got no objections to it, we're happy to negotiate with them and talk to them to work in with the elders and government officials," Mr Richter said.  He said while the company had entered into discussions with the NT government and Northern Land Council (NLC) over excising part of their land, he was now awaiting the next move from government.  "From our side of it, we've replied to the government," he said.  "The ball's in their court."  The NLC has also voiced its frustration over the slow pace of negotiations.  Pigeon Hole residents used boats to travel through floodwaters earlier in January. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  Part of the reason for not moving sooner, the government says, is because in previous years some Pigeon Hole residents have said they wanted to stay where they are.  "I think with anything, you'll find that there'll be people who don't want to move," Ms Lawler said.  "But it is an ongoing conversation.  "I think the flood last year … they hadn't had a flood for a long time, then this second one is probably now making people think very carefully around the situation they're in."  Ms Pollock was among residents who told the ABC there was now unison within the community about wanting to move to higher ground.  Residents say they are worried about flooding every year. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  Footage shows accommodation flooded  Less than 12 months since the Victoria River last broke its banks, the temporary accommodation that had been trucked in for workers helping to rebuild the community was this month inundated.  Over the past year, the NT government has spent more than $11 million repairing and replacing flood-inundated homes in the communities of Pigeon Hole, Kalkarindji and Dagaragu.  Portable buildings installed by the NT government last year have already flooded. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  Power was cut during flooding earlier this month. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  Mr Pedwell is among those to question why the NT government would build and bring new infrastructure into the flood plain on Pigeon Hole, rather than make plans to relocate.  "Half-built houses have been inundated with floodwater as we speak," Mr Pedwell said.  "No new infrastructure is being done up on the higher ground – if there was, I wouldn't be talking to you, I wouldn't be advocating on the community's behalf."  Gurindji leader Rob Roy described building the homes in Pigeon Hole as "money down the drain every year".  "I don't know how much a house cost to build, about $500,000?" he said.  "Build a few of those every year that get washed away, what's the government doing?"  Rob Roy says the NT government is wasting money by continuing to build homes in a flood zone. ( ABC News: Hamish Harty )  Mr Richter also said he was "shocked" to see new homes being built.  "I was quite shocked to see them start building new houses [on the flood plain]," he said.  "In all honesty, it's a waste of our taxpayer's money."  Ms Lawler defended placing the accommodation back in Pigeon Hole's flood zone.  "You know, that's where the community is, and that's probably been there for a very, very long time," she said.  "So it was about upgrading and the new houses were houses that were built with a large slab, so that was above the flood levels."  Several houses are under construction on the flood plain. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  The Department of Infrastructure said the "contractor's accommodation received some inundation from the floodwaters" this month.  "The temporary accommodation being utilised by the community residents were not impacted by floodwaters," a spokesperson said.  "Some materials for the new homes [currently being built] have received damage from the floodwater, however, the extent of this is still to be determined as the contractors are yet to return to the community."  'If only the government listened to us'  Pigeon Hole resident Jocelyn Victor said some people had been pushing to relocate the community since 2001 when major flooding prompted the NT government to move the local power station and airstrip to higher ground.  "It's not fair," she said.  Jocelyn Victor with her partner Raymond Hector in Pigeon Hole. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  "It's terrible leaving us in the flood zone."  Ms Victor said she was still traumatised by last year's major flooding event, which destroyed residents' houses and swept away precious belongings.  She hasn't seen her pet dog since.  "We've lived so many years in our own houses and losing everything just like that, it hurt terribly," she said.  After the devastation from last year, Ms Victor chose to stay behind at a makeshift shelter near Pigeon Hole this time rather than join the evacuees in Darwin.  She said it's not a choice residents should have to make each wet season.  "It would make it easier if the government moved the school, the shop and the clinic up to higher ground — and the housing — instead of sending people away from their home," she said.  About 30 people stayed at a temporary flood shelter near Pigeon Hole during the most recent flooding. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector )  "If only the government listened to us, instead of … pouring more money into building houses down there.  "The future for our younger generation isn't looking good if the government keeps building houses in the flood zone area."  Ms Pollock also chose to stay behind at the shelter near Pigeon Hole during last week's flooding.  She said all the residents agreed the community should move to higher ground.  "We've been screaming out to move to higher ground since the floods of 2001," she said.  Watch 7.30, Mondays to Thursdays 7.30pm on ABC iview and ABC TV
soup_text: NT community of Pigeon Hole flooded twice in 12 months, as calls grow to relocate to higher ground - ABC News This site uses cookies The ABC uses cookies to improve your experience. Learn more about how we use cookies Accept all cookies ABC required cookies only Skip to main content ABC News Homepage Search Log In Log In More from ABC Just In Watch Live Politics World Business Analysis Sport More Science Health Entertainment Lifestyle Fact Check Other News Home ABC News Homepage NT community of Pigeon Hole flooded twice in 12 months, as calls grow to relocate to higher ground Share NT community of Pigeon Hole flooded twice in 12 months, as calls grow to relocate to higher ground 7.30 / By Matt Garrick and Samantha Dick Posted 3h ago 3 hours ago Wed 31 Jan 2024 at 1:25am , updated 1h ago 1 hours ago Wed 31 Jan 2024 at 2:43am An aerial view of the remote community of Pigeon Hole after major flooding in March last year. ( Supplied ) abc.net.au/news/pigeon-hole-floods-twice-in-one-year-amid-pleas-to-relocate/103390936 Copy link Link copied Share Share article In the aftermath of the latest flood to inundate her outback community, teacher Anne Pollock went to check on the state of her beloved workplace, the Pigeon Hole school. This time around, it had managed to avoid serious devastation. Less than 12 months earlier, however, the same building wasn't so fortunate. The floors were left caked in hardened mud, with schoolbooks and classroom resources badly damaged and destroyed. Floodwaters damaged property at the Pigeon Hole school in March 2023. ( Supplied ) For Ms Pollock, seeing her tiny outback Northern Territory community hit by floods from a swelling Victoria River twice in less than a year has proved a difficult pill to swallow. "It was terrible, devastating you know?" the Bilinara and Mudburra woman said. "Repeating the trauma again. "After the flood last year, I lost a lot of my stuff from my house." Anne Pollock says the flooding events have been "devastating" for residents. ( ABC News: Evelyn Manfield ) Dozens of residents were evacuated from Pigeon Hole — also known as Nitjpurru — earlier this month, as the river hit a 30-year peak of 24 metres, during a deluge from the tropical monsoon. Located more than 700 kilometres south of Darwin and built on a flood plain, residents and local authorities have been calling for Pigeon Hole to be relocated to higher ground for decades. Mayor of the Victoria Daly Regional Council Brian Pedwell has been raising his voice over the issue to the NT government for years , so far to no avail. "I'm very angry. I've been angry for the last 20 years to relocate that community," he said. "Those departments, when are they going to look at themselves deeply and relocate that infrastructure … how many more times that community gonna flood?" Brian Pedwell has spent years pushing the NT government to move Pigeon Hole to higher ground. ( ABC News: Mike Donnelly ) Government says it supports relocating Pigeon Hole NT Chief Minister Eva Lawler denied that the government had long ignored the requests of Pigeon Hole residents to relocate, and said negotiations were underway with a nearby cattle station for access to higher land. "There is an absolute will to do that [relocation]," Ms Lawler said. "These things cost money, and it is moving a whole community, and you know, there are people that have lived there for a very long time." She didn't commit to a firm timeline and said there could be compensation involved with the move. "With the pastoralists, you know, there will need to be land that'll be excised, it might involve compensation, and then it will be around that process of moving," she said. Some of the houses sit on short stilts, but residents say it's not enough to escape floodwaters. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) The NT government built more houses on the flood plain in 2018. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) Founded by Australia's first billionaire, Robert Holmes à Court, Heytesbury Pastoral owns the Victoria River Downs station next to Pigeon Hole. Station general manager Rusty Richter said the station had "no objections" to excising part of the station land for the town, but that they'd received very little information from the NT government. "Heytesbury's got no objections to it, we're happy to negotiate with them and talk to them to work in with the elders and government officials," Mr Richter said. He said while the company had entered into discussions with the NT government and Northern Land Council (NLC) over excising part of their land, he was now awaiting the next move from government. "From our side of it, we've replied to the government," he said. "The ball's in their court." The NLC has also voiced its frustration over the slow pace of negotiations. Pigeon Hole residents used boats to travel through floodwaters earlier in January. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) Part of the reason for not moving sooner, the government says, is because in previous years some Pigeon Hole residents have said they wanted to stay where they are. "I think with anything, you'll find that there'll be people who don't want to move," Ms Lawler said. "But it is an ongoing conversation. "I think the flood last year … they hadn't had a flood for a long time, then this second one is probably now making people think very carefully around the situation they're in." Ms Pollock was among residents who told the ABC there was now unison within the community about wanting to move to higher ground. Residents say they are worried about flooding every year. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) Footage shows accommodation flooded Less than 12 months since the Victoria River last broke its banks, the temporary accommodation that had been trucked in for workers helping to rebuild the community was this month inundated. Over the past year, the NT government has spent more than $11 million repairing and replacing flood-inundated homes in the communities of Pigeon Hole, Kalkarindji and Dagaragu. Portable buildings installed by the NT government last year have already flooded. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) Power was cut during flooding earlier this month. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) Mr Pedwell is among those to question why the NT government would build and bring new infrastructure into the flood plain on Pigeon Hole, rather than make plans to relocate. "Half-built houses have been inundated with floodwater as we speak," Mr Pedwell said. "No new infrastructure is being done up on the higher ground – if there was, I wouldn't be talking to you, I wouldn't be advocating on the community's behalf." Gurindji leader Rob Roy described building the homes in Pigeon Hole as "money down the drain every year". "I don't know how much a house cost to build, about $500,000?" he said. "Build a few of those every year that get washed away, what's the government doing?" Rob Roy says the NT government is wasting money by continuing to build homes in a flood zone. ( ABC News: Hamish Harty ) Mr Richter also said he was "shocked" to see new homes being built. "I was quite shocked to see them start building new houses [on the flood plain]," he said. "In all honesty, it's a waste of our taxpayer's money." Ms Lawler defended placing the accommodation back in Pigeon Hole's flood zone. "You know, that's where the community is, and that's probably been there for a very, very long time," she said. "So it was about upgrading and the new houses were houses that were built with a large slab, so that was above the flood levels." Several houses are under construction on the flood plain. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) The Department of Infrastructure said the "contractor's accommodation received some inundation from the floodwaters" this month. "The temporary accommodation being utilised by the community residents were not impacted by floodwaters," a spokesperson said. "Some materials for the new homes [currently being built] have received damage from the floodwater, however, the extent of this is still to be determined as the contractors are yet to return to the community." 'If only the government listened to us' Pigeon Hole resident Jocelyn Victor said some people had been pushing to relocate the community since 2001 when major flooding prompted the NT government to move the local power station and airstrip to higher ground. "It's not fair," she said. Jocelyn Victor with her partner Raymond Hector in Pigeon Hole. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) "It's terrible leaving us in the flood zone." Ms Victor said she was still traumatised by last year's major flooding event, which destroyed residents' houses and swept away precious belongings. She hasn't seen her pet dog since. "We've lived so many years in our own houses and losing everything just like that, it hurt terribly," she said. After the devastation from last year, Ms Victor chose to stay behind at a makeshift shelter near Pigeon Hole this time rather than join the evacuees in Darwin. She said it's not a choice residents should have to make each wet season. "It would make it easier if the government moved the school, the shop and the clinic up to higher ground — and the housing — instead of sending people away from their home," she said. About 30 people stayed at a temporary flood shelter near Pigeon Hole during the most recent flooding. ( Supplied: Raymond Hector ) "If only the government listened to us, instead of … pouring more money into building houses down there. "The future for our younger generation isn't looking good if the government keeps building houses in the flood zone area." Ms Pollock also chose to stay behind at the shelter near Pigeon Hole during last week's flooding. She said all the residents agreed the community should move to higher ground. "We've been screaming out to move to higher ground since the floods of 2001," she said. article_title: NT community of Pigeon Hole flooded twice in 12 months, as calls grow to relocate to higher ground

article_text: As Australia eagerly anticipates the Powerball's $200 million draw on Thursday night, the nation is abuzz with the possibility of life-changing moments. This record jackpot, the largest in Australian lottery history, has captured the imagination of countless individuals dreaming of the instant their lives could transform with a single phone call from lotto officials.  This draw, unprecedented in its magnitude, follows six consecutive draws without a division one winner. With up to half of Australian adults expected to participate, the draw is set to be a historic event.  Ahead of Thursday night’s heart-stopping Powerball draw, The Lott has showcased some of the awe-inspiring moments when previous division one winners discovered their wins.  The $200 million prize is the biggest jackpot offered by any Australian lottery game in history. It comes after no player held all seven winning numbers and the all-important Powerball number needed to win the division one prize in the past six consecutive draws.  Up to half of Australian adults are expected to have an entry into the draw, vying for the chance to become a newly minted multi-millionaire.  The Lott spokesperson Anna Hobdell said a tapestry of emotions often unfold when delivering the news of a division one windfall.  “Behind every winning lottery call, there’s a person on the other end of the line with a story to tell. It’s a privilege to be part of these life-changing moments that can redefine someone’s life,” she said.  “From the heart-pounding moment of anticipation to the overwhelming joy that erupts when the division one news truly sinks in, it’s an emotional journey like no other.  “Securing a significant lottery win frequently evokes genuine tears of joy, astonished gasps, or even momentary stunned silence.  “Winning a slice of the record-breaking $200 million Powerball prize would be a phone call to remember for eternity and would undoubtedly change your life for many decades to come.  “In 2019, we revealed a $107 million Powerball win to a Sydney mum minutes after the draw – a phone call that she will never forget.  “As we broke the life-changing news to the New South Wales woman and crowned her the biggest individual lottery winner in history, there was a moment of silence on the other end of the line, which was later followed by an outpour of emotion.”  The Sydney nurse, in her 40s, continues to wake up and go to work, devoting her life to helping others in need.  Lottery officials caught up with the pink-collar worker a year after her win to see how winning a slice of the multi-million-dollar win changed her life.  “I got up the next morning and took the kids to school and had jobs to do and commitments I had to follow through with,” she told The Lott in July 2020.  “People needed me to be the person I always was.  “I suppose you get to a certain age, and you’re already the person you are, and you’re set in a certain way. When you’ve had these certain habits your whole life, you don’t just change them overnight, or at least I chose not to.”  For the chance to experience a division one winning phone call like the Sydney nurse, Ms Hobdell said she recommended players register their entry to a player card or online account.  “The team at The Lott headquarters and I will be on the edge of our seats, ready to reach out to any registered division one winners on Thursday night. But we can only call if the player has registered their ticket and kept their contact details up to date,” she said.  “If you see your phone light up on Thursday night, be sure to pick up immediately because it could be The Lott calling with some life-altering division one news!”  The peak of sales for last week’s $150 million Powerball draw was at 6:15pm on the day of the draw when 7,445 tickets were sold in a single minute.  Tickets into the $200 million Powerball draw 1446 can be purchased at any licensed lottery outlet, online from thelott.com or via The Lott mobile app before the draw’s close at 7.30pm AEST on Thursday 1 February 2024.  In 2023, 20 Powerball division one winning entries across Australia pocketed more than $552.15 million in prize money.  During this time, a Bankstown dad scored a $100 million jackpot and became the second-biggest Australian lottery winner of all time.  Of the 20 Powerball division one winning entries in 2023, eight landed in New South Wales, seven in Victoria, two each in South Australia and Western Australia, and one in Queensland.  Note: Amidst the excitement and promotions, potential players should play responsibly and recognize their slim chances of claiming a slice of this massive jackpot. Winning the division one prize in Powerball, which requires matching all seven winning numbers plus the Powerball number in a single game panel, is no small feat.  The odds of securing the division one prize with a standard game are 1 in 134,490,400 – an almost unfathomable level of improbability.  Comparing these odds to everyday events is challenging because such odds are far beyond any daily experiences during lifetime. You can think of it as it's like finding a specific grain of sand on a large beach. Or the rough lifetime odds of you being injured by lightning strikes are approximately 1 in 3,200 in Australia , and given 1 in 10 victims die according to the ABS data, then the lifetime odds of being killed by lightning in Australia are about 1 in 32,000.  As such, while the dream of winning big is a thrilling prospect, it's important for players to approach the draw with realistic expectations and an understanding of the incredibly long odds they face.

Of the 20 Powerball division one winning entries in 2023, eight landed in New South Wales, seven in Victoria, two each in South Australia and Western Australia, and one in Queensland. Note: Amidst the excitement and promotions, potential players should play responsibly and recognize their slim chances of claiming a slice of this massive jackpot. Winning the division one prize in Powerball, which requires matching all seven winning numbers plus the Powerball number in a single game panel, is no small feat. The odds of securing the division one prize with a standard game are 1 in 134,490,400 – an almost unfathomable level of improbability. Comparing these odds to everyday events is challenging because such odds are far beyond any daily experiences during lifetime. You can think of it as it's like finding a specific grain of sand on a large beach. Or the rough lifetime odds of you being injured by lightning strikes are approximately 1 in 3,200 in Australia , and given 1 in 10  victims die according to the ABS data, then the lifetime odds of being killed by lightning in Australia are about 1 in 32,000. As such, while the dream of winning big is a thrilling prospect, it's important for players to approach the draw with realistic expectations and an understanding of the incredibly long odds they face. Lottery officials caught up with the pink-collar worker a year after her win to see how winning a slice of the multi-million-dollar win changed her life.  “I got up the next morning and took the kids to school and had jobs to do and commitments I had to follow through with,” she told The Lott in July 2020.  “People needed me to be the person I always was.  “I suppose you get to a certain age, and you’re already the person you are, and you’re set in a certain way. When you’ve had these certain habits your whole life, you don’t just change them overnight, or at least I chose not to.”  For the chance to experience a division one winning phone call like the Sydney nurse, Ms Hobdell said she recommended players register their entry to a player card or online account.  “The team at The Lott headquarters and I will be on the edge of our seats, ready to reach out to any registered division one winners on Thursday night. But we can only call if the player has registered their ticket and kept their contact details up to date,” she said.  “If you see your phone light up on Thursday night, be sure to pick up immediately because it could be The Lott calling with some life-altering division one news!”  The peak of sales for last week’s $150 million Powerball draw was at 6:15pm on the day of the draw when 7,445 tickets were sold in a single minute.  Tickets into the $200 million Powerball draw 1446 can be purchased at any licensed lottery outlet, online from thelott.com or via The Lott mobile app before the draw’s close at 7.30pm AEST on Thursday 1 February 2024.  In 2023, 20 Powerball division one winning entries across Australia pocketed more than $552.15 million in prize money.  During this time, a Bankstown dad scored a $100 million jackpot and became the second-biggest Australian lottery winner of all time.  Of the 20 Powerball division one winning entries in 2023, eight landed in New South Wales, seven in Victoria, two each in South Australia and Western Australia, and one in Queensland.  Note: Amidst the excitement and promotions, potential players should play responsibly and recognize their slim chances of claiming a slice of this massive jackpot. Winning the division one prize in Powerball, which requires matching all seven winning numbers plus the Powerball number in a single game panel, is no small feat.  The odds of securing the division one prize with a standard game are 1 in 134,490,400 – an almost unfathomable level of improbability.  Comparing these odds to everyday events is challenging because such odds are far beyond any daily experiences during lifetime. You can think of it as it's like finding a specific grain of sand on a large beach. Or the rough lifetime odds of you being injured by lightning strikes are approximately 1 in 3,200 in Australia , and given 1 in 10 victims die according to the ABS data, then the lifetime odds of being killed by lightning in Australia are about 1 in 32,000.  As such, while the dream of winning big is a thrilling prospect, it's important for players to approach the draw with realistic expectations and an understanding of the incredibly long odds they face.

article_text: Vacuum cleaner retail chain Godfreys has collapsed, with cost of living pressures blamed for fewer sales and contributing to a "challenging economic and operating environment" for the business to remain viable.  Key points: Godfreys has entered voluntary administration while looking for a potential buyer for the vacuum cleaner retailer  Godfreys has entered voluntary administration while looking for a potential buyer for the vacuum cleaner retailer The business has struggled with maintaining its profitability due to reduced customer demand and higher operational costs  The business has struggled with maintaining its profitability due to reduced customer demand and higher operational costs Administrators expect 54 Godfreys stores will close within the fortnight, affecting 193 jobs in Australia and New Zealand  Since its establishment in 1931, Godfreys evolved to become one of the world's biggest vacuum cleaner retailers, and operates 141 stores employing more than 600 people across Australia and New Zealand.  On Tuesday afternoon, Godfreys announced it had entered voluntary administration, appointing PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) to oversee the process.  In a statement, the administrators said the Godfreys business would continue to trade while it undergoes an "immediate" restructure of its operations, which is expected to result in the closure of 54 stores and loss of 193 staff in the next 14 days.  "Like many retailers, Godfreys has faced a challenging economic and operating environment," administrator Craig Crosbie said.  "Lower customer demand amid cost of living pressures, higher operating costs, and increased competition have all taken a toll on profitability, with some stores more impacted than others.  "Our aim is to move quickly to restructure Godfreys to preserve as much of the business and as many jobs as possible."  Mr Crosbie said the administrators would also seek a buyer for the business while keeping the remaining stores operational.  "We intend to trade the restructured store network and sell the business and assets as a going concern, with strong interest expected from prospective buyers," he said.  "We will continue to work closely with Godfreys' director, management, and creditors, including staff whose employment is unfortunately impacted by store closures."  In a statement, Godfreys' director Grant Hancock said it was a "difficult" decision to place the business into administration.  "While the decision to appoint administrators was difficult, it was made with the best interests of Godfreys' employees, customers and broader stakeholders in mind," he said.  Administrators will hold their first creditors meeting on February 9.  Administrators expect there will be "strong interest" for Godfreys from prospective buyers. ( Facebook: Godfreys )  A brand built on a bowling ball  The eponymous retailer was founded in Melbourne by Godfrey Cohen at a time when vacuum cleaners were exclusively sold by door-to-door salesmen in Australia.  In 1931, Mr Cohen spent $50 — the equivalent of $2,700 today — to purchase 30 vacuum cleaners from the auction columns of a newspaper, and displayed them in the window of his family's furniture shop.  Five years later, Mr Cohen struck a deal with businessman John Johnston and the pair opened the first Godfreys store in Melbourne's Prahran Market.  The retailer gradually expanded to other locations and became a vacuum retailing empire, with more than 220 stores locations across Australia and New Zealand at its peak.  Godfreys became well-known for its advertising campaigns in the 1990s starring its chief executive, John Hardy, who famously demonstrated the strength and suction power of vacuum cleaners by picking up a 7-kilogram bowling ball.  YouTube Godfreys' bowling ball advertisement demonstrated a vacuum's suction by having it pick up a 7kg bowling ball.  Mr Cohen died in 2004 at the age of 95, and the company was sold to private equity firms Pacific Equity Partners and Unitas Capital in 2006 for $350 million.  In 2014, Godfreys became a publicly listed company on the Australian Securities Exchange, but falling sales, increased competition, senior management changes and a waning share price resulted in the company being taken private four years later.  Mr Johnston bought back the vacuum cleaner retailer he founded in mid-2018 for $13.7 million, and died months later aged 100.  At the time of his death, Mr Hardy said one of the reasons Mr Johnston bought back the company he co-founded "was because he could see a great long-term future for the business under private ownership".

article_text: In short: NSW Police are offering a $500,000 reward to help solve the suspected murder of a Sydney man, gunned down on his way to Canberra almost 40 years ago.  NSW Police are offering a $500,000 reward to help solve the suspected murder of a Sydney man, gunned down on his way to Canberra almost 40 years ago. They say the murder may have been "politically motivated".  They say the murder may have been "politically motivated". What's next? Police are hoping anyone with information about the case, or who was in the car with Mr Djordjevic on his way to Canberra, to come forward.  New South Wales police have appealed for information in what they have called a "last throw of the dice" to solve a nearly 40-year-old cold case murder.  On January 26, 1985, western Sydney resident Radojko Djordjevic left home to meet his wife and some of his children at the Bojic church festival in Canberra.  When he failed to show up, his wife reported him missing to police.  A newspaper clipping published following the murder. ( Supplied: NSW Police )  Five days later, police found his decomposed body near the Hume Highway at Marulan.  He had been shot three times in the neck and chest.  A coronial report found he had likely died between 9.30pm on Thursday January 24 and 11am on Thursday January 31, 1985.  Ever since, his family, including daughter Gana, has been searching for answers.  "I had just turned 21 when our father was brutally bashed and then shot three times – my brother Dragan was 19, Milan was 13 and Miladin was 10," Ms Djordevic said.  "I am 60 now, and we are desperately still seeking closure to the continuous grieving, suffering and insecurity caused by my father's death."  'Political motivations'  Today, NSW Police announced a $500,000 reward for information regarding Mr Djordjevic's murder.  They said they believed the killing "may have been politically motivated", and related to a "political power struggle" within Serbian organisations in NSW at the time.  Mr Djordjevic was said to be a prominent member of western Sydney's Serbian community at the time of his death.  He was the president of both the Free Serbian Orthodox Church and the Old Toongabbie branch of the Liberal Party.  Mr Djordjevic's daughter Gana said the family held suspicions about who her father was in the car with around the time of his death.  Radojko Djordjevic's children are still seeking answers to his murder. ( Supplied: NSW Police )  "My father was unlicenced at the time of his killing, which tells us he wasn't driving a car and the person or persons responsible for this is someone we may have considered family friends," she said.  NSW Police Detective Acting Superintendent Virginia Gorman said that information was crucial to their investigation.  "Our information is that he potentially was picked up by people in a car and taken into Canberra," she said.  "We've not definitely identified who those people may be, so anybody in that car could be of particular interest, or anybody who was in that car who wants to come forward and tell us about what happened, it'd be much appreciated."  Ms Gorman said now was the time to appeal to the public to come forward before those with information died.  "It's 39 years since this occurred, members of the family are getting older, members of the public who might have information about this are also getting older," she said.  "So at a time like now you offer reward, it might be the time when we're really a long way distance from those internal conflicts that maybe people will now be happier to talk about what was going on at the time, and who may have been involved."  An old crime scene photo from the investigation into Radojko Djordjevic's murder. ( Supplied: NSW Police )  A man was arrested in 2003 and charged with Mr Djordjevic's murder, but was later acquitted.  NSW Police Minister Yasmin Catley said there was still hope the case could be solved.  "It's been 39 years the Djordevic family has been without answers – but police still believe there are people out there who could lead them to the missing piece of the puzzle," Ms Catley said.
soup_text: Half-a-million dollar reward offered for information in 39-year-old cold case murder of Radojko Djordjevic in NSW - ABC News This site uses cookies The ABC uses cookies to improve your experience. Learn more about how we use cookies Accept all cookies ABC required cookies only Skip to main content ABC News Homepage Search Loading More from ABC Just In Watch Live Politics World Business Analysis Sport More Science Health Entertainment Lifestyle Fact Check Other News Home ABC News Homepage Half-a-million dollar reward offered for information in 39-year-old cold case murder of Radojko Djordjevic in NSW Share Half-a-million dollar reward offered for information in 39-year-old cold case murder of Radojko Djordjevic in NSW By Victor Petrovic Posted 17h ago 17 hours ago Tue 30 Jan 2024 at 11:04am , updated 17h ago 17 hours ago Tue 30 Jan 2024 at 11:23am .Radojko Djordjevic's family has been searching for answers since his death in 1985. ( Supplied: NSW Police ) abc.net.au/news/reward-offered-cold-case-sydney-man-radojko-djordjevic/103405540 Copy link Link copied Share Share article In short: NSW Police are offering a $500,000 reward to help solve the suspected murder of a Sydney man, gunned down on his way to Canberra almost 40 years ago. They say the murder may have been "politically motivated". What's next? Police are hoping anyone with information about the case, or who was in the car with Mr Djordjevic on his way to Canberra, to come forward. New South Wales police have appealed for information in what they have called a "last throw of the dice" to solve a nearly 40-year-old cold case murder. On January 26, 1985, western Sydney resident Radojko Djordjevic left home to meet his wife and some of his children at the Bojic church festival in Canberra. When he failed to show up, his wife reported him missing to police. A newspaper clipping published following the murder. ( Supplied: NSW Police ) Five days later, police found his decomposed body near the Hume Highway at Marulan. He had been shot three times in the neck and chest. A coronial report found he had likely died between 9.30pm on Thursday January 24 and 11am on Thursday January 31, 1985. Ever since, his family, including daughter Gana, has been searching for answers. "I had just turned 21 when our father was brutally bashed and then shot three times – my brother Dragan was 19, Milan was 13 and Miladin was 10," Ms Djordevic said. "I am 60 now, and we are desperately still seeking closure to the continuous grieving, suffering and insecurity caused by my father's death." 'Political motivations' Today, NSW Police announced a $500,000 reward for information regarding Mr Djordjevic's murder. They said they believed the killing "may have been politically motivated", and related to a "political power struggle" within Serbian organisations in NSW at the time. Mr Djordjevic was said to be a prominent member of western Sydney's Serbian community at the time of his death. He was the president of both the Free Serbian Orthodox Church and the Old Toongabbie branch of the Liberal Party. Mr Djordjevic's daughter Gana said the family held suspicions about who her father was in the car with around the time of his death. Radojko Djordjevic's children are still seeking answers to his murder. ( Supplied: NSW Police ) "My father was unlicenced at the time of his killing, which tells us he wasn't driving a car and the person or persons responsible for this is someone we may have considered family friends," she said. NSW Police Detective Acting Superintendent Virginia Gorman said that information was crucial to their investigation. "Our information is that he potentially was picked up by people in a car and taken into Canberra," she said. "We've not definitely identified who those people may be, so anybody in that car could be of particular interest, or anybody who was in that car who wants to come forward and tell us about what happened, it'd be much appreciated." Ms Gorman said now was the time to appeal to the public to come forward before those with information died. "It's 39 years since this occurred, members of the family are getting older, members of the public who might have information about this are also getting older," she said. "So at a time like now you offer reward, it might be the time when we're really a long way distance from those internal conflicts that maybe people will now be happier to talk about what was going on at the time, and who may have been involved." An old crime scene photo from the investigation into Radojko Djordjevic's murder. ( Supplied: NSW Police ) A man was arrested in 2003 and charged with Mr Djordjevic's murder, but was later acquitted. NSW Police Minister Yasmin Catley said there was still hope the case could be solved. "It's been 39 years the Djordevic family has been without answers – but police still believe there are people out there who could lead them to the missing piece of the puzzle," Ms Catley said. article_text: Channel Nine has apologised to Victorian MP Georgie Purcell after she accused the broadcaster of using a digitally altered image of her in its TV news bulletin.      Purcell, a member of the Animal Justice Party, said on Tuesday that Nine News had enlarged her breasts and made it appear as though she was wearing a crop top in a graphic used to introduce its story on the Victorian government rejecting calls for a ban on duck hunting.      "Note the enlarged boobs and outfit to be made more revealing," Purcell wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter.      "Can’t imagine this happening to a male MP."    Hugh Nailon, director of Nine News Melbourne, apologised for what he said was a "graphic error".      "Our graphics department sourced an online image of Georgie to use in our story on duck hunting," Nailon said in a statement.      "As is common practice, the image was resized to fit our specs.      "During that process, the automation by Photoshop created an image that was not consistent with the original."      Nailon added this did not meet Nine News' "high editorial standards" and said it apologised to Purcell "unreservedly".      Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan said it was not an appropriate way to treat any woman, let alone a woman holding a position in public office.

Victorian Animal Justice Party MP Georgie Purcell posted an image shown on Channel 9 (left) saying it was digitally altered from the original (right). Credit: Nine News / Twitter Channel Nine has apologised to Victorian MP Georgie Purcell after she accused the broadcaster of using a digitally altered image of her in its TV news bulletin. Purcell, a member of the Animal Justice Party, said on Tuesday that Nine News had enlarged her breasts and made it appear as though she was wearing a crop top in a graphic used to introduce its story on the Victorian government rejecting calls for a ban on duck hunting. "Note the enlarged boobs and outfit to be made more revealing," Purcell wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter. "Can’t imagine this happening to a male MP." Hugh Nailon, director of Nine News Melbourne, apologised for what he said was a "graphic error". "Our graphics department sourced an online image of Georgie to use in our story on duck hunting," Nailon said in a statement. "As is common practice, the image was resized to fit our specs. "During that process, the automation by Photoshop created an image that was not consistent with the original." Nailon added this did not meet Nine News' "high editorial standards" and said it apologised to Purcell "unreservedly". Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan said it was not an appropriate way to treat any woman, let alone a woman holding a position in public office. "Let's think about the image that sends particularly to young women." soup_text: Sydney Harbour shark attack leaves woman severely injured - BBC News BBC Homepage Skip to content Accessibility Help Your account Home News Sport Earth Reel Worklife Travel More menu More menu Search BBC Home News Sport Earth Reel Worklife Travel Culture Future Music TV Weather Sounds Close menu BBC News Menu Home Israel-Gaza war War in Ukraine Climate Video World Asia UK Business Tech More Science Entertainment & Arts Health World News TV In Pictures BBC Verify Newsbeat World Africa Australia Europe Latin America Middle East US & Canada Sydney Harbour shark attack leaves woman severely injured Published 22 hours ago Share close panel Share page Copy link About sharing Image source, Getty Images Image caption, Shark attacks in Sydney Harbour are rare By Tiffanie Turnbull BBC News, Sydney A woman has suffered severe injuries after she was attacked by a shark during a sunset swim in Australia. Lauren O'Neill, 29, was bitten on the leg near a private wharf in Sydney Harbour on Monday evening. Locals residents administered first aid after hearing Ms O'Neill call for help. She was taken to hospital in a serious but stable condition. Authorities believe a bull shark is responsible for the attack, based on photographs of the bite marks. Sydney Harbour is a well-known habitat for the species, but attacks in the area are rare. Neighbour Michael Porter told the Sydney Morning Herald (SMH) he heard a "soft yell" for help outside his window around 20:00 local time (09:00 GMT). He looked outside to see Ms O'Neill hanging on to a ladder on the wharf in Elizabeth Bay, an inner-city suburb. "She was trying to climb in and behind her was her leg, which was completely open and full of dark red blood behind her," Mr Porter said. Another local described how her wife, who is a vet, applied a tourniquet to stem the bleeding. "She basically bandaged it up. The bone's broken and it's pretty hectic actually," Georgia Singleton told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. One witness told the SMH she regularly sees sharks swimming under the jetty. "I always thought it was a matter of time," she said. In 2009, former navy diver Paul de Gelder was left without an arm and a leg after he was attacked by a bull shark during a counter-terrorism exercise in Sydney Harbour. Australia has more shark attacks than any other country except the US, but fatal attacks are uncommon. There were 14 shark attacks in 2023, according to the Australian Shark-Incident Database, four of them lethal. article_text: The director of public prosecutions has been asked to consider whether criminal charges should be laid over the death of an Aboriginal teenager who was killed when the trail bike he was riding collided with an unmarked police car in Sydney.  On Tuesday, the New South Wales state coroner, Teresa O’Sullivan, suspended the inquest into the death of Dunghutti teenager Jai Kalani Wright and referred the case to the DPP.  Wright, 16, died while riding in Eveleigh in February 2022.  The inquest, which had only started on Monday and was set down for two weeks, was expected to investigate issues including the roles played by police officers in the collision and whether it was appropriate for them to attempt to stop Wright, the Aboriginal Legal Service (NSW/ACT), which was representing Wright’s parents in the proceedings, said.  In a statement, Wright’s parents, Lachlan Wright and Kylie Aloua, asked family and friends to respect the referral process.  “Almost 2 years ago, we received a call, one of the calls that as a parent you never want to receive, about Jai having an accident. We rushed straight to the hospital and we were by our son’s side as he passed away.  “Ever since then, we have been searching for the truth. We need to know the truth so that we can live our lives and move forward.  “This referral has given us a lot of hope, we have faith that we will get justice for Jai. I would just ask all our family and friends to let this process play out … and believe that at the end we will get our truth and get our justice.”  View image in fullscreen Lachlan Wright (right) embraces supporters after the inquest into Jai’s death was suspended and referred to the DPP. Photograph: Bianca de Marchi/AAP  Karly Warner, the CEO of the Aboriginal Legal Service (NSW/ACT), said that Wright was one of at least 558 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who have died in custody and police operations in three decades since the royal commission.  “Scrutiny and accountability are essential in stopping this national shame,” Warner said.  “The Aboriginal Legal Service is proud to stand alongside Jai Wright’s family and community. We share their immense grief and determination to ensure what happened to Jai never happens again.”  skip past newsletter promotion Sign up to Morning Mail Free daily newsletter Our Australian morning briefing breaks down the key stories of the day, telling you what’s happening and why it matters Enter your email address Enter your email address Sign up Privacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy . We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. after newsletter promotion  The inquest heard on Monday that NSW police believed the bike Wright was riding had been stolen, along with a black Mercedes and a white BMW, on the morning of the collision.  Counsel assisting the coroner, Peggy Dwyer SC, told the court on Monday that officers were ordered to stay in the area but not to pursue the stolen vehicles.  But soon after, according to CCTV and in-car video footage played to the court, Sergeant Benedict Bryant could be seen swinging his unmarked police car in front of the trail bike, which then collided with it at high speed.  Dwyer said Bryant did not activate his lights or siren.  The DPP previously considered the case but decided against charging Bryant.  Additional reporting by Australian Associated Press.
